tit.e: Musa no kuni no miyatsuko (regional governor in ancient Japan)
tit.cmt: (government post) government postには違いないと思いますが、これだと中央官僚のようにも聞こえるので、regional governor in ancient Japan（古代日本の地域の統括者）としました。
tit.e: Musa no kuni no miyatsuko (regional governor in ancient Japan)

sen.j: 武社国造（むさのくにのみやつこ・むさこくぞう)は上総国北東部を支配した国造。
sen.e: Musanokuninomiyatsuko 武社国造 (also known as Musakokuzo) was kuninomiyatsuko ruled the northeast part of Kazusa Province.
Musa no kuni no miyatsuko (武社国造), also known as Musa kokuzo, was a kuni no miyatsuko that ruled the northeast part of Kazusa Province in ancient Japan.
Musa no kuni no miyatsuko (武社国造), also known as Musa kokuzo, was a kuni no miyatsuko that ruled the northeast part of Kazusa Province in ancient Japan.
It was also written as 牟邪国造.
It was also written as 牟邪国造.

He was an older brother of Oketsuhime.

sen.j: 成務天皇朝に孫の彦忍人命が武社国造になったという。
sen.e: It is said that his grandson Hikooshihitonomikoto became Musanokuninomiyatsuko during the reign of Emperor Seimu.
It is said that his grandson Hikooshihito no mikoto became Musa no kuni no miyatsuko during the reign of Emperor Seimu.
It is said that his grandson Hikooshihito no mikoto became Musa no kuni no miyatsuko during the reign of Emperor Seimu.

Kabane was probably Atai.

sen.j: 和珥氏・小野氏・丈部氏などと同系。
sen.e: The clan was descended from the same line as the Wani clan, the Ono clan, and the Hatsusekabe clan,
The clan was descended from the same line as the Wani clan, the Ono clan, and the Hatsusekabe clan,

sen.j: 渡来系の身狭(牟佐)氏(姓は村主)とは別系とされる。
sen.e: It is considered the Musashi clan (Kabane was Suguri) that was from China and Korea was in the different line from that of Hikooshihitonomikoto.
Another Musashi clan (the same name with a different set of characters, its Suguri was its family title) is considered to be a different line.
Another Musashi clan (the same name with a different set of characters, its Suguri was its family title) is considered to be a different line.
